1566570350_1Dssbq2y2JDD14aojGG9RX3d5EPpw.body:
> [humboldt](#comment_12_1A3HXsg9nYdffV3gBNDN5NDpdZE1xBq8Ra): I guess capitalism makes you think of monopoly. But monopolism does not exist in capitalism, monopolies are formed only by state violence and lobbyism. If the state did not interfere, subsidize and benefit itself, it would not exist. The banking system today is also anti-capitalist. It is slavery.

Exactly. A simple thought experiment is that you literally cannot create a monopoly without interference. Look at the board game for example. You're forced to use the pre-existing lots for purchase and you have to place amenities in the order the game allows. You're not allowed to create any more space in the unused areas on the board.

The lack of self awareness for anti-capitalists is astonishing.

1566671185_1GFU4qAMTFnQJ7W7r98Zj2xJWq1ev.body: This screed is all nice and good, but when someone breaks the guidelines, who's enforcing punishment? If someone is enforcing punishment, then who enforces the enforcer? Greed can't be law'd out of existence and there are loopholes for every piece of legislation. At least when you leave it open, you can hit back at corporate espionage. The second you make it against the rules, you put power in the hands of the elite.

This post is also an autistic push for "intellectual property" when really we should be moving away from that. If I take inspiration from nature and create something which someone takes inspiration from to create something else, what right do I have to tell them they can't do that? Unless they are plagiarizing my work and calling it their own, there should really be no issue. Apply that same concept to this scenario around OSS.

1567571648_1BBxotsHK1A6e7uRD6N29qVSMMCSm.body:
This has already been done, multiple times. You seem to forget that the larger social networks are operated either in tandem or under the direct influence of the government (except for Twitch - we have Amazon to thank for that), which is the only reason why they are still around. Without the state's intervention, every social network would have gone with the wind, replaced by another. That is the nature of the free market.

Instead, what we are seeing now is the artificial extension of the lifespan of a social network. Twitter, for example, has the POTUS and Congress members use it as an official platform for information dissemination. Facebook is the reincarnation of DARPA's lifelog. YouTube is owned by Google, an organization that has hired former members of Congress in key positions at the company. Now, you have Sergey Brin and Larry Page rubbing shoulders with politicians.

With this government influence at the top 3 social networks, they can extend their reach as laws and special privileges become accessible to them, maintaining their positions of power. Any other network or site would've died in their position, especially once they begin to undermine their audience and start losing money (much like Twitter has), yet here they still are.

In short, no my friend. They will not be tasting their own medicine unless literally every user held them accountable for the same things they hold others to account for. Which, as you should expect, will never happen. So people will continue to provide data for social media to sell to third parties and government officials. Collusion has never been so *in your face* as of this age.
